result.query:
Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: In this study, novel Schottky-junction photocatalysts Bi-metal-deposited g-C 3 N 4 were constructed via a one-step solvothermal process for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under simulated irradiation.The photocatalytic performance illustrated that the nanohybrid catalysts have extreme activity and excellent stability.The maximum CO yield of 3.78 mol h -1 g -1 was reached on the BiCN-0.6 hybrid, which was about 3 times as much as that of pure g-C 3 N 4 .The phase, microstructure, and optical and

reactions of all as-fabricated samples under simulated light irradiation were performed and presented in Figure 7.According to the control experimental results, no hydrocarbon products were detected in the dark environment or without catalyst, demonstrating that the light irradiation and catalysts were all essential for photocatalysis.Figure 7a displays the CO evolution with time.The CO production over BiCN-0.6 attains the maximum of 26.42 mol g -1 during 7 h of illumination, which is about 2.9 times that

is mainly ascribed to the introduction of Bi.When the Bi spheres are exposed to visible light, the collective oscillation of electrons on the surface of Bi spheres is generated by the SPR effect to form a strong electric field, which can propel g-C 3 N 4 to capture more photons. 69Meanwhile, a Schottky barrier is formed because of the difference of the work function between g-C 3 N 4 and Bi spheres, implying that Bi could act as an electron-acceptor candidate in the hybrids for CO 2 photoreduction. 70The

for CO 2 photoreduction. 70The detailed reaction process is ascribed as follows: Under light illumination, the abundant photoexcited electrons accumulated on the CB of g-C 3 N 4 will be transferred to the Bi metal as a result of the Fermi level of Bi metal -0.17 eV versus normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) being much more positive than that of CB of g-C 3 N 4 , resulting in the effective spatial charge separation. 71Afterward, the holes on the VB of g-C 3 N 4 will react with H 2 O to produce H and O 2 because

in pure g-C 3 N 4 and its poor light-harvesting ability.Therefore, this phenomenon may be conjectured that the incorporation of Bi metal facilitates charge transfer and reduces the recombination rate as a result of the formation of a built-in electric field caused by the SPR effect. 61However, an excessive increase of Bi for the compound would restrain the production of CO, which is associated with the blocked light harvesting and the increased recombination centers.Moreover, the photocatalytic stability

Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
Light_source: XXX
Lamp: XXX

is mainly ascribed to the introduction of Bi.When the Bi spheres are exposed to visible light, the collective oscillation of electrons on the surface of Bi spheres is generated by the SPR effect to form a strong electric field, which can propel g-C 3 N 4 to capture more photons. 69Meanwhile, a Schottky barrier is formed because of the difference of the work function between g-C 3 N 4 and Bi spheres, implying that Bi could act as an electron-acceptor candidate in the hybrids for CO 2 photoreduction. 70The

nanohybrids show surprising enhancement from the visible light to nearinfrared (NIR) region (450-2500 nm) with the increase of the Bi-depositing content, arising from background absorption and a charge-transfer transition through the interface. 58Thus, the boosted light harvesting of BiCN nanohybrids plays a major role in photogenerating more charge carriers to accelerate the reaction of CO 2 photoreduction.In addition, no significant absorption edge shift of BiCN photocatalysts is detected in comparison

transmission of photoexciton in g-C 3 N 4 and BiCN catalysts.Figure 8a exhibits the photocurrent response pattern under irradiation of simulated sunlight in 5 repeated light on-off cycles.BiCN hybrids inherit the carrier transfer properties of pure g-C 3 N 4 and display higher photocurrent intensities.Among them, BiCN-0.6 exhibits the strongest current intensity, implying the fast separation of electrons and holes.To confirm this conclusion, the EIS test was performed and presented in Figure 8b.The

microstructure, and optical and photoelectrochemical properties were demonstrated by related characterization methods.The improvement mechanism could be ascribed to the enhanced photon absorption capacity and the decreased recombination rate of photoinduced carriers arising from the Schottky barrier in the system.This work may provide a meaningful approach to enhance the photocatalytic activity through a simple and green strategy.
